entries.content: Focus on the opening of a cold call.
entries.notes: A good opening is critical for bypassing gatekeepers and engaging prospects.

entries.content: Avoid pitching or selling in the opening of a cold call.
entries.notes: Doing so typically leads to immediate disqualification or rejection.

entries.content: On initial outbound calls, your primary objective is to gather information, not to sell immediately.
Do not assume your pitch will instantly convert a prospect into a customer.
entries.notes: This is a common mistake; the pitch's job is different.

entries.content: The pitch should aim to pique the prospect's interest.
The pitch should make the prospect understand the need for a further conversation.
entries.notes: Highlight a potential pain point or missed opportunity.

entries.content: (Bad Opening Example) "Hey, I want to talk to the person that handles your [area] because we help [type] businesses with [benefit]."
entries.notes: This direct, pitching style opening is often shut down by gatekeepers.

entries.content: (Good Opening Example) "Hey, I was just doing some research on the area/your business and saw that you guys do [specific thing you noticed]."
entries.notes: Use a research-based opening to sound less salesy and typical.

entries.content: Frame your call as simple outreach based on research, not a direct sales pitch.
"I'm not really sure (why I'm calling). I was just doing some research and this [thing you noticed] came up."
entries.notes: Use this phrase after the research-based opening to pique curiosity without pressure, encouraging a transfer.

entries.content: Avoid putting pressure, asking for things, or selling upfront to encourage gatekeepers to transfer you to the decision maker.
The primary objective of the initial cold call is to reach the decision maker.
Once connected with the decision maker, your objective is to gather information to assess if you can provide value.
If you identify that you can help the decision maker, schedule a follow-up meeting to discuss further.
entries.notes: Do not try to close on the first call.

entries.content: Keep initial calls short and simple.
